author: Christian Gollayan
title: Keep this ingredient out of your cocktail, scientists warn | New York Post
text:
Better think twice before ordering a vodka-Red Bull.
A recent study at the University of Victoria in Canada found that mixing alcohol with energy drinks increases your risk for injury, according to EurekAlert. 
Combing through 13 studies spanning 35 years, researchers found that the “wide-awake” buzz from mixing alcohol — a depressant — with a caffeine drink — a stimulant — makes imbibers more prone to accidents, fights and physical violence than if they’d stuck to booze alone.
The problem, according to lead study author Audra Roemer, is that the turbocharged combination keeps drinkers out past their prime. “The stimulant effects of caffeine mask the result that most people get when they drink,” Roemer, a research assistant at the University of Victoria and the lead study author, explained in a press release. “Usually when you’re drinking alcohol, you get tired and you go home. Energy drinks mask that, so people may underestimate how intoxicated they are, end up staying out later, consume more alcohol, and engage in risky behavior and more hazardous drinking practices.”
According to another study by Purdue University , mixing these two substances had an identical result on mice’s brains as doing cocaine.
“It seems the two substances together push them over a limit that causes changes in their behavior and changes the neurochemistry in their brains,” Richard van Rijn, an assistant professor at Purdue University, wrote in a press release. “We’re clearly seeing effects of the combined drinks that we would not see if drinking one or the other.”
